III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff responsibilities.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation Back in March 2024 the agency had to retrieve the children from a
relative’s home after they were left home alone, and the police
were contacted. The agency could not obtain a clearance on
another relative who had come to the home to try to care for them
until the caregiver arrived, so the children were taken to the
agency for the night.
The children were sent to school by the agency staff the next day
in too small and dirty clothing.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant: On 6/5/2024 I interviewed Complainant by
telephone. Complainant reported during a DHHS (Department of
Health and Human Services) audit of departmental reports, the
issues as indicated in this complaint were observed in a report,
with the primary concern being that the children, Child A, Child B
and Child C were sent to school by the agency with dirty, too small
clothing, after they had spent the night at the agency.
2

Complainant reported per a DHHS report the agency staff took the
children from the caregiver’s home after the caregiver had not
returned to the home from work. The children’s transport to the
agency was also after the agency was unable to obtain a
children’s services clearance on the children’s grandmother who
had arrived at the home and was not the approved substitute
caregiver. Complainant further reported it was reported by P2P
(Pathway to Potential) Specialist that the children’s school
principal told P2P Specialist the information that was reported
about the children’s clothing. Complainant reported the school
principal would have direct information about what is alleged
about the children’s clothing.
Pathway to Potential Specialist: On 6/14/2024 I interviewed
Pathway to Potential (P2P) Specialist about the allegations by
telephone. P2P Specialist reported her position was via the state
of Michigan whereby she was stationed at the school. She works
indirectly with students looking at attendance issues, process cash
assistance, and help children and families who may be homeless.
She said she was not at school on the day of the alleged incident.
She was told about the incident the next day. She was told the
children were dropped off with McDonald’s breakfast. They came
disheveled with dirty clothes, and they appeared to not have
showered. The principal gave them clothes and a toothbrush and
may have given them shoes. P2P Specialist said she researched
the case, saw the children were assigned to Holy Cross and that
there was a DHHS investigation. P2P Specialist reported she may
have emailed the DHHS worker and left a message on Teams but
she was not certain. She said since DHHS was involved in the
matter she did not do anything further.
Principal: On 6/14/2024 I interviewed Principal of School M. She
verified that an agency staff transported Child A and Child B to
school, on a day in early March 2024. The worker advised them of
the situation for the children and had purchased McDonalds for
the children. Principal reported the children’s clothing were the
same as the day before, but they were not dirty or too small. She
said the children’s appearance in regard to other children at the
school was fine and better than many. She said the school is
equipped with dealing with varies situation like this and they
arranged for the children to get cleaned up, provided toothbrushes
to them. Principal reported Child A’s shoes were too small, and
the agency worker offered to go purchased him shoes, but she
advised the worker the school had items for situations like this
one. The school gave Child A shoes. Child B was also given
shoes “not because she needed them” Child B saw the shoes and
3

liked them. Principal reported the school had no fault with the
agency’s handling of the situation.
Foster Care Supervisor: On 6/26/2024 I interviewed Foster Care
Supervisor (FCS) about the allegations by telephone. FCS
confirmed Child A’s, Child B’s and Child C’s case was supervised
by the agency. She reported the agency received a call late in the
evening one day in March of 2024 that the children’s relative
Caregiver was not at home with the children. That Caregiver had
gone out of state. Upon calling Caregiver and being unable to
reach Caregiver, the agency conducted a safety check at the
home with the police. There was a support person, believed to be
Caregiver’s mother, “Person X” with the children. The agency did
not know this person. The agency had no documented substitute
caregiver on file for/from Caregiver. Since they did not know
Person X, did not have clearance paperwork on file for Person X,
the agency contacted DHHS intake in an attempt to get Person X
cleared, given the emergence of the situation. DHHS intake would
not complete the central registry clearance. DHHS intake reported
since the agency was requesting the clearance for a substitute
care provider, not a new placement for the children, the agency
needed to follow up and complete the central registry clearance
the next day. FCS reported given what was reported by DHHS
intake, and that Caregiver still was not answering her phone, they
took the children to the agency. They attempted to locate an
emergency placement for the children, while still trying to connect
with Caregiver to see when Caregiver might come for the children.
FCS reported those calls were occurring around 10:00PM and
onward, but they were not able to locate a foster home willing to
take the three children. Around midnight Caregiver called back to
say she would be at the agency by 2:00AM to pick up the children.
Caregiver never arrived and never called back. The children
spent the night at the agency supervised by FCS and Foster Care
Worker (FCW). Caregiver picked the children up from school the
next day.
FCS reported this was the first incident of this type or with
Caregiver. Caregiver is not licensed but is now pursuing licensure.
FCS said she and FCW transported the children to school the next
day. FCS took Child C to school, and FCW took Child A and Child
B. The agency purchased a McDonald’s breakfast for the children
and advised the school about the children’s situation. FCS denied
the children’s clothing being too small or dirty, but reported their
clothing was what they had worn the day before. She reported the
agency did not have clothing at the agency that would
accommodate the children, because their clothing closet primarily
4

had infant clothing. They had checked the clothing closet the night
before for clothing and bedding.
Foster Care Worker: On 6/27/2024 I interviewed FCW about the
allegations by telephone. FCW reported the situation and chain of
events similar to the FCS. FCW clarified that they were notified of
the Caregiver not being at the home after 8:00PM. The children
were with Caregiver’s two older teen sons when the police arrived.
FCW and FCS arrived at Caregiver’s home and Person X was on
her way to the home. Additionally, at one point in the evening
Caregiver reported she was not in Texas, was in Michigan, and
was unable to leave work timely because of the person she was
caring for. Caregiver wanted the agency to see if they could clear
Person X to be with the children.
FCW reported the children spent the night at the agency’s office
because the agency was unable to reach Caregiver about her
return home to retrieve the children (despite numerous calls), or to
obtain an after-hour central registry clearance on Person X, or to
secure a respite foster home for the children. She said the agency
did all they could related to trying to find a proper placement for
the children; they did not want to have to spend the night at the
office.
FCW affirmed she and FCS purchased McDonald’s breakfasts for
the children and she took the older two children to school. She
spoke with someone in the school’s office about the children’s
situation. The office was familiar with the children and did not
express any concerns.
FCW also said the children’s clothing were the ones they had on
from the day before. She denied the children’s clothing being dirty,
too small, or smelling. She acknowledged a change of clothing for
the children would have been best, if they could have done that.
She reported they did not have access to the children’s home to
get them a change of clothing. They did not have clothing for the
children in their clothing closet, or access to petty cash to
purchase clothing. She said their primary concern that evening
was getting the children and making sure they were safe and the
next day ensuring they did not miss school.
Document Review
Child A’s, Child B’s and Child C’s MISACWIS case record which
showed:
• The children were placed in Caregiver’s home on 1/5/2023.
5

• The children were made temporary court wards on
1/5/2023.
• The children were returned to the parental home on
7/12/2024.
• A social work contact for 3/4/2024 that indicated:
o The incident similar to what FCW had reported when
she was interviewed.
o Another person, a male, had arrived at the home
reporting he was taking the children so as to take them
to school the next day, and the agency advised the
officers not to allow that person to take the children.
The FCW and FCS came and transported the children
to the office.
o FCW attempted to call Caregiver at 12:30am. The
Caregiver texted and said that she was driving as fast
as she could to get back, but the Caregiver never
showed up, and FCW FCS spent the night at the office
with the children.
o Caregiver texted FCW at 6:15 AM reporting she got a
flat tire on her way home from meeting with a client in
Traverse City and that her friend was picking her up at
9 AM
o The agency made a complaint to DHHS intake about
the situation.
A DHHS report that showed:
• An investigation conducted on 3/5/2024 indicated reports
were made that Caregiver left for Texas, leaving the
children home alone. The children were seen in the home
on 3/04/2024 during a home visit completed by their
caseworker.
• An email was received from P2P Specialist that stated she
spoke with someone, and the school was concerned about
the children because they came to school on 3/6/2024 “with
too small of clothing, and dirty” after spending the night at
the foster care office.
• There were no reports the children were harmed as a result
of being home alone.
Analysis Based on interviews and documentation reviewed the evidence
does not show a lack of work by the worker/agency with the
children, their families, and other relevant individuals related to the
service plans for the children and their families. The agency
sought to supervise the children.
Consultation:
6

From a best practice standard, it could be beneficial to the agency
to have hygiene items and older children clothing on hand for
emergency situations.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
